Requesting the most recent inspection information on the University of Washington's animal labs. The University of Washington (UW) is currently constructing a new animal lab, costing $124 million, in order to expand its animal testing facilities. UW has the dubious distinction of being one of only eight institutions in the U.S. continuing to subject primates—along with dogs, bunnies, and rats—in laboratories. Over the years, UW’s animal labs have been cited numerous times for animal welfare violations by numerous organizations, including: the Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care (2007), Stop Animal Exploitation Now! (2013), and the United States Department of Agriculture (2014). Apparently, time has not improved conditions for the animals housed in the UW labs. I would like to see recent inspection records in order to ensure UW is treating its current lab animal humanely; otherwise, the expansion of its animal testing facilities is absolutely immoral, representing an expansion of illegal animal cruelty. The most recent inspection record available on the USDA's Animal Care Information System Tool is November 2014. This seems odd to me, because the previous inspections occur roughly 3 months apart. Why is there such a large gap from the November 2014 inspection until now? (Date Range for Record Search: From 11/18/2014 To 09/13/2015)

Request information in association with statements presented by U.S Fish and Wildlife Service in the extended version of the August 26, 2015, Federal Register notice for Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES); Seventeenth Regular Meeting: Taxa Being Considered for Amendments to the CITES Appendices. The specific information requested is: 1. All information and data that supports the conclusion that the areas of CITES conservation concern for American ginseng (Panax quinquefolius) [whole and sliced roots, root parts] are equally valued in the ginseng market, such as interviews with ginseng marketers and dealers, surveys of retailers in the Asian consumer market, websites selling whole and sliced wild roots for comparable prices, etc.; and ? 2. Any information or evidence that documents situations in which cultivated ginseng has been used to smuggle or sell wild ginseng illegally, to support the statement that “once ginseng roots are sliced, it is difficult to distinguish whether such roots were cultivated or harvested from the wild.”
